content.description:
Begin 20' right of

Be Wary

(5.2). Climb face to reach left-angling thin crack to flake.

https://www.antwiki.org/wiki/Myrmecocystus_ewarti
content.protection: Some webbing and a few pieces if toproping.

climbs.name: Morituri Te Salutamus
climbs.fa: Ted Chapin and Jim Boone, October 1979

content.description: Start up the easy flake of Myrmecocysus Ewarti. Branch off right and climb a short crux overhang, then continue on easy ground to the top.
content.location: This shares a start with Myrmecocysus Ewarti.

content.description:
Start 15' right of

Flies on the Wound

(5.7) up prominent chimney.
content.protection: Some webbing and a few pieces if toproping.

content.description: Climb up the mound to start, after which you will find your first real move to get up the to obvious right foot; then most make one traverse move to the left and then climb up the thin face.
content.protection: Tope rope on trad gear anchor, can be shared with chimney to the left. No bolts, no directional except for running the rope over the top of the climb.
content.location: Starts just to the right of the chimney "Hillside Strangler." Climb the face, and a bit of the arete on the right.

climbs.name: Flies on the Wound
climbs.fa: Ted Chapin, Bill Fournier & Jim Boone, 10/79

content.description:
The best line at Morbid Mound.  The route starts in the middle of the south face, about 15' left of

Hillside Strangler

, the prominent chimney.  Gain steep vertical crack and patina plates with positive holds.
content.protection: Some webbing and a few pieces if toproping.

climbs.name: DOA
climbs.fa: Todd Swain, Jim Schlinkman, Kip Knapp & Patty Furbush, March 1986

content.description:
On the south face of the Morbid Mound a crack system lies perhaps 5-8 meters right of the left edge. This is Bouncer.

Just left of that, near the left edge, is this slab route that climbs the face past a few horizontals up top. Not much good for pro her. Â It is harder, or at least more insecure than Bouncer - don't fall!

You can get a good "butt belay" stance above it that is secure to bring up a partner.
content.protection: No pro really. Solo it or get a pad and spotter, which probably isn't enough?  Or maybe a TR?

climbs.name: Disappearing Belayer
climbs.fa: Ted Chapin and Jim Boone, October 1979

content.description: This route takes the fat flake just left of Be Wary. Starts up Be Wary, transfers out to the flake at about 10' off the deck. Fun transition moves, and std ow/squeeze (or lieback) to the top of the flake where it eases.
content.protection: If leading (most will solo or TR), take the largest piece you own #4 camalot or bigger and maybe a couple pieces from fingers to hands. Build your own anchor with either gear or slinging large boulders.
content.location: Middle of the south face, on the left wall of a dihedral system is an obvious fat flake. Descend by either walking off the back on obvious low angle terrain, or downclimbing Brimstone Stairway.

climbs.name: Deadheads
climbs.fa: Todd Swain, Patty Furbush, Kip Knapp, Colette Bein & Jim Schlinkman, 3/86

content.description:
Start as for

Brimstone Stairway

(5.1 R). About half way up, traverse right along small ledge and continue to top.
content.protection: Some long webbing and a few pieces if toproping.

content.description: Follow the prominent "staircase" with giant edges on SW side of formation.  An easy solo or good choice for introducing beginners to basic movement on rock.  Descend off NW side of formation or downclimb route.
content.protection: Long webbing and a few pieces if toproping.

climbs.name: Bouncer
climbs.fa: Unknown  FFA: Jim Boone & Ted Chapin, 10/79

content.description: On the south face of Morbid Mound is a crack system perhaps 5-8 meters right of the left edge of the formation. This climbs up easy moves (I did not bother protecting) a few meters to a stance on a ledge, then up a finger crack system, perhaps anohther 6 meters to the top, where a good "butt belay" stance can be had to bring up the second. The pro I used was a few cams ~ 1" size, and placed just above the good stance at mid-route.  Well protected, moderate.

climbs.name: Be Wary of Your Physician's Assistant

content.description: Wonderful steep face climbing on small edges and friction, albeit short.
content.location: On the south face of Morbid Mound, between "Be Wary" and "Ambulance Driver."

content.protection: Some webbing and a few pieces if toproping.

content.description: See the photo for topo. Crux is about mid-way through the second roof.
content.protection: good selection of small to medium cams
content.location: It is a notable crack on the right side of the southface roof system.

climbs.name: 3rd Class It
climbs.fa: Jim Boone and Ted Chapin, October 1979

content.description: Around the corner, to the left of the main south face routes, is this route through steep black patina. Starts up a boulder on the desert floor, pulls into a varnished bowl. The committing pull into the bowl puts you directly below a handish crack with a smaller fingercrack/overlap just to its left. Beware some loose crystal chunks in the bottom of the handcrack. Work both cracks to exit. Not much to this one, but it's kind of exciting on the solo since the crux is the exit.
content.protection: Nuts and a couple cams fingers to hands.
content.location: The combination of black patina, a boulder to start off of and the "bowl" is pretty obvious. About 20' left and around the corner from DOA.

content.description:
Follows the left-angling crack/flake 15' right of

Be Wary

(5.2).
content.protection: Some webbing and a few pieces if toproping.

climbs.name: 'Til Death Do Us Fart
climbs.fa: Todd Swain, Kip Knapp, and Jim Schlinkman, March 1986

content.description: A crux lieback up a thin vertical crack takes you up to a fun 5.10 roof. Easier climbing leads to the top.
content.location: This is the crack system just right of Myrmecocysus Ewarti.
